       5             : 
       6             : // The Gecko Profiler is an always-on profiler that takes fast and low overhead
       7             : // samples of the program execution using only userspace functionality for
       8             : // portability. The goal of this module is to provide performance data in a
       9             : // generic cross-platform way without requiring custom tools or kernel support.
      10             : //
      11             : // Samples are collected to form a timeline with optional timeline event
      12             : // (markers) used for filtering. Both "periodic" (in response to a timer) and
      13             : // "synchronous" (in response to an explicit sampling request via the API)
      14             : // samples are supported.
      15             : //
      16             : // The profiler collects samples that include native stacks and
      17             : // platform-independent "pseudostacks".
      18             : 
      19             : #ifndef SAMPLER_H
      20             : #define SAMPLER_H
      21             : 
      22             : #include <stdint.h>
      23             : #include <stdarg.h>
      24             : 
      25             : #include "MainThreadUtils.h"
      26             : #include "mozilla/Assertions.h"
      27             : #include "mozilla/Attributes.h"
      28             : #include "js/TypeDecls.h"
      29             : #include "mozilla/GuardObjects.h"
      30             : #include "mozilla/UniquePtr.h"
      31             : #include "mozilla/Vector.h"
      32             : #include "nsString.h"
      33             : 
      34             : class SpliceableJSONWriter;

      37             : class TimeStamp;

      60             :   mozilla::UniquePtr<ProfilerBacktrace, ProfilerBacktraceDestructor>;
      61             : 
      62             : #if !defined(MOZ_GECKO_PROFILER)
      63             : 
      64             : // Use these for functions below that must be visible whether the profiler is
      65             : // enabled or not. When the profiler is disabled they are static inline
      66             : // functions (with a simple return value if they are non-void) that should be
      67             : // optimized away during compilation.
      68             : #define PROFILER_FUNC(decl, rv)  static inline decl { return rv; }
      69             : #define PROFILER_FUNC_VOID(decl) static inline void decl {}
      70             : 
      71             : // Insert an RAII object in this scope to enter a pseudo stack frame. Any
      72             : // samples collected in this scope will contain this label in their pseudo
      73             : // stack. The name_space and info arguments must be string literals.
      74             : // Use PROFILER_LABEL_DYNAMIC if you want to add additional / dynamic
      75             : // information to the pseudo stack frame.
      76             : #define PROFILER_LABEL(name_space, info, category) do {} while (0)
      77             : 
      78             : // Similar to PROFILER_LABEL, PROFILER_LABEL_FUNC will push/pop the enclosing
      79             : // functon name as the pseudostack label.
      80             : #define PROFILER_LABEL_FUNC(category) do {} while (0)
      81             : 
      82             : // Enter a pseudo stack frame in this scope and associate it with an
      83             : // additional string.
      84             : // This macro generates an RAII object. This RAII object stores the str
      85             : // pointer in a field; it does not copy the string. This means that the string
      86             : // you pass to this macro needs to live at least until the end of the current
      87             : // scope.
      88             : // If the profiler samples the current thread and walks the pseudo stack while
      89             : // this RAII object is on the stack, it will copy the supplied string into the
      90             : // profile buffer. So there's one string copy operation, and it happens at
      91             : // sample time.
      92             : // Compare this to the plain PROFILER_LABEL macro, which only accepts literal
      93             : // strings: When the pseudo stack frames generated by PROFILER_LABEL are
      94             : // sampled, no string copy needs to be made because the profile buffer can
      95             : // just store the raw pointers to the literal strings. Consequently,
      96             : // PROFILER_LABEL frames take up considerably less space in the profile buffer
      97             : // than PROFILER_LABEL_DYNAMIC frames.
      98             : #define PROFILER_LABEL_DYNAMIC(name_space, info, category, str) do {} while (0)
      99             : 
     100             : // Insert a marker in the profile timeline. This is useful to delimit something
     101             : // important happening such as the first paint. Unlike profiler_label that are
     102             : // only recorded if a sample is collected while it is active, marker will always
     103             : // be collected.
     104             : #define PROFILER_MARKER(info) do {} while (0)
     105             : #define PROFILER_MARKER_PAYLOAD(info, payload) do { mozilla::UniquePtr<ProfilerMarkerPayload> payloadDeletor(payload); } while (0)
     106             : 
     107             : #else   // defined(MOZ_GECKO_PROFILER)
     108             : 
     109             : #define PROFILER_FUNC(decl, rv)  decl;
     110             : #define PROFILER_FUNC_VOID(decl) void decl;
     111             : 
     112             : // we want the class and function name but can't easily get that using preprocessor macros
     113             : // __func__ doesn't have the class name and __PRETTY_FUNCTION__ has the parameters
     114             : 
     115             : #define PROFILER_LABEL(name_space, info, category) MOZ_PLATFORM_TRACING(name_space "::" info) mozilla::SamplerStackFrameRAII SAMPLER_APPEND_LINE_NUMBER(sampler_raii)(name_space "::" info, category, __LINE__)
     116             : 
     117             : #define PROFILER_LABEL_FUNC(category) MOZ_PLATFORM_TRACING(SAMPLE_FUNCTION_NAME) mozilla::SamplerStackFrameRAII SAMPLER_APPEND_LINE_NUMBER(sampler_raii)(SAMPLE_FUNCTION_NAME, category, __LINE__)
     118             : 
     119             : #define PROFILER_LABEL_DYNAMIC(name_space, info, category, str) MOZ_PLATFORM_TRACING(name_space "::" info) mozilla::SamplerStackFrameDynamicRAII SAMPLER_APPEND_LINE_NUMBER(sampler_raii)(name_space "::" info, category, __LINE__, str)
     120             : 
     121             : #define PROFILER_MARKER(info) profiler_add_marker(info)
     122             : #define PROFILER_MARKER_PAYLOAD(info, payload) profiler_add_marker(info, payload)
     123             : 
     124             : #endif  // defined(MOZ_GECKO_PROFILER)
     125             : 
     126             : // These functions are defined whether the profiler is enabled or not.
     127             : 
     128             : // Adds a tracing marker to the PseudoStack. A no-op if the profiler is
     129             : // inactive or in privacy mode.
     130             : PROFILER_FUNC_VOID(profiler_tracing(const char* aCategory, const char* aInfo,
     131             :                                     TracingKind aKind = TRACING_EVENT))

     133             :                                     UniqueProfilerBacktrace aCause,
     134             :                                     TracingKind aKind = TRACING_EVENT))
     135             : 
     136             : // Initialize the profiler. If MOZ_PROFILER_STARTUP is set the profiler will be
     137             : // started. This call must happen before any other profiler calls (except
     138             : // profiler_start(), which will call profiler_init() if it hasn't already run).
     139             : PROFILER_FUNC_VOID(profiler_init(void* stackTop))
     140             : 
     141             : // Clean up the profiler module, stopping it if required. This function may
     142             : // also save a shutdown profile if requested. No profiler calls should happen
     143             : // after this point and all pseudo labels should have been popped.
     144             : PROFILER_FUNC_VOID(profiler_shutdown())
     145             : 
     146             : // Start the profiler -- initializing it first if necessary -- with the
     147             : // selected options. Stops and restarts the profiler if it is already active.
     148             : // After starting the profiler is "active". The samples will be recorded in a
     149             : // circular buffer.
     150             : //   "aEntries" is the number of entries in the profiler's circular buffer.
     151             : //   "aInterval" the sampling interval, measured in millseconds.
     152             : PROFILER_FUNC_VOID(profiler_start(int aEntries, double aInterval,
     153             :                                   const char** aFeatures,
     154             :                                   uint32_t aFeatureCount,
     155             :                                   const char** aThreadNameFilters,
     156             :                                   uint32_t aFilterCount))
     157             : 
     158             : // Stop the profiler and discard the profile without saving it. A no-op if the
     159             : // profiler is inactive. After stopping the profiler is "inactive".
     160             : PROFILER_FUNC_VOID(profiler_stop())
     161             : 
     162             : // Pause and resume the profiler. No-ops if the profiler is inactive. While
     163             : // paused the profile will not take any samples and will not record any data
     164             : // into its buffers. The profiler remains fully initialized in this state.
     165             : // Timeline markers will still be stored. This feature will keep JavaScript
     166             : // profiling enabled, thus allowing toggling the profiler without invalidating
     167             : // the JIT.
     168             : PROFILER_FUNC_VOID(profiler_pause())
     169             : PROFILER_FUNC_VOID(profiler_resume())
     170             : 
     171             : // Is the profiler active and paused? Returns false if the profiler is inactive.
     172             : PROFILER_FUNC(bool profiler_is_paused(), false)
     173             : 
     174             : // Immediately capture the current thread's call stack and return it. A no-op
     175             : // if the profiler is inactive or in privacy mode.
     176             : PROFILER_FUNC(UniqueProfilerBacktrace profiler_get_backtrace(), nullptr)
     177             : 
     178             : PROFILER_FUNC_VOID(profiler_get_backtrace_noalloc(char *output,
     179             :                                                   size_t outputSize))
     180             : 
     181             : // Free a ProfilerBacktrace returned by profiler_get_backtrace().
     182             : #if !defined(MOZ_GECKO_PROFILER)
     183             : inline void ProfilerBacktraceDestructor::operator()(ProfilerBacktrace* aBacktrace) {}
     184             : #endif
     185             : 
     186             : // Is the profiler active? Note: the return value of this function can become
     187             : // immediately out-of-date. E.g. the profile might be active but then
     188             : // profiler_stop() is called immediately afterward. One common and reasonable
     189             : // pattern of usage is the following:
     190             : //
     191             : //   if (profiler_is_active()) {
     192             : //     ExpensiveData expensiveData = CreateExpensiveData();
     193             : //     PROFILER_OPERATION(expensiveData);
     194             : //   }
     195             : //
     196             : // where PROFILER_OPERATION is a no-op if the profiler is inactive. In this
     197             : // case the profiler_is_active() check is just an optimization -- it prevents
     198             : // us calling CreateExpensiveData() unnecessarily in most cases, but the
     199             : // expensive data will end up being created but not used if another thread
     200             : // stops the profiler between the CreateExpensiveData() and PROFILER_OPERATION
     201             : // calls.
     202             : //
     203             : PROFILER_FUNC(bool profiler_is_active(), false)
     204             :

     316             : class nsISupports;
     317             : class ProfilerMarkerPayload;
     318             : 
     319             : // Each thread gets its own PseudoStack on thread creation. ThreadInfo has the
     320             : // owning reference; tlsPseudoStack is a non-owning reference. On thread
     321             : // destruction, tlsPseudoStack is cleared, and the ThreadInfo (along with its
     322             : // PseudoStack) may or may not be destroyed.
     323             : //
     324             : // Non-owning PseudoStack references are also temporarily used by
     325             : // profiler_call_{enter,exit}() pairs. RAII classes ensure these calls are
     326             : // balanced, and they occur on the thread itself, which means they are
     327             : // necessarily bounded by the lifetime of the thread, which ensures they can't
     328             : // be used after the PseudoStack is destroyed.
     329             : //
     330             : extern MOZ_THREAD_LOCAL(PseudoStack*) tlsPseudoStack;
     331             : 
     332             : class ProfilerState;
     333             : 
     334             : // The core profiler state. Null at process startup, it is set to a non-null
     335             : // value in profiler_init() and stays that way until profiler_shutdown() is
     336             : // called. Therefore it can be checked to determine if the profiler has been
     337             : // initialized but not yet shut down.
     338             : extern ProfilerState* gPS;
     339             : 
     340             : #ifndef SAMPLE_FUNCTION_NAME
     341             : # if defined(__GNUC__) || defined(_MSC_VER)
     342             : #  define SAMPLE_FUNCTION_NAME __FUNCTION__
     343             : # else
     344             : #  define SAMPLE_FUNCTION_NAME __func__  // defined in C99, supported in various C++ compilers. Just raw function name.
     345             : # endif
     346             : #endif
     347             : 
     348             : // Returns a handle to pass on exit. This can check that we are popping the
     349             : // correct callstack. Operates the same whether the profiler is active or not.
     350             : static inline void*

     353             :                     void *aFrameAddress, bool aCopy, uint32_t line,
     354             :                     const char* aDynamicString = nullptr)

     394             : 
     395             : // Uncomment this to turn on systrace or build with
     396             : // ac_add_options --enable-systace
     397             : //#define MOZ_USE_SYSTRACE
     398             : #ifdef MOZ_USE_SYSTRACE
     399             : #ifndef ATRACE_TAG
     400             : # define ATRACE_TAG ATRACE_TAG_ALWAYS
     401             : #endif
     402             : // We need HAVE_ANDROID_OS to be defined for Trace.h.
     403             : // If its not set we will set it temporary and remove it.
     404             : # ifndef HAVE_ANDROID_OS
     405             : #   define HAVE_ANDROID_OS
     406             : #   define REMOVE_HAVE_ANDROID_OS
     407             : # endif
     408             : // Android source code will include <cutils/trace.h> before this. There is no
     409             : // HAVE_ANDROID_OS defined in Firefox OS build at that time. Enabled it globally
     410             : // will cause other build break. So atrace_begin and atrace_end are not defined.
     411             : // It will cause a build-break when we include <utils/Trace.h>. Use undef
     412             : // _LIBS_CUTILS_TRACE_H will force <cutils/trace.h> to define atrace_begin and
     413             : // atrace_end with defined HAVE_ANDROID_OS again. Then there is no build-break.
     414             : # undef _LIBS_CUTILS_TRACE_H
     415             : # include <utils/Trace.h>
     416             : # define MOZ_PLATFORM_TRACING(name) android::ScopedTrace SAMPLER_APPEND_LINE_NUMBER(scopedTrace)(ATRACE_TAG, name);
     417             : # ifdef REMOVE_HAVE_ANDROID_OS
     418             : #  undef HAVE_ANDROID_OS
     419             : #  undef REMOVE_HAVE_ANDROID_OS
     420             : # endif
     421             : #else
     422             : # define MOZ_PLATFORM_TRACING(name)
     423             : #endif
     424             : 
     425             : // FIXME/bug 789667: memory constraints wouldn't much of a problem for this
     426             : // small a sample buffer size, except that serializing the profile data is
     427             : // extremely, unnecessarily memory intensive.
     428             : #ifdef MOZ_WIDGET_GONK
     429             : # define PLATFORM_LIKELY_MEMORY_CONSTRAINED
     430             : #endif
     431             : 
     432             : #if !defined(PLATFORM_LIKELY_MEMORY_CONSTRAINED) && !defined(ARCH_ARMV6)
     433             : # define PROFILE_DEFAULT_ENTRIES 1000000
     434             : #else
     435             : # define PROFILE_DEFAULT_ENTRIES 100000
     436             : #endif
     437             : 
     438             : // In the case of profiler_get_backtrace we know that we only need enough space
     439             : // for a single backtrace.
     440             : #define GET_BACKTRACE_DEFAULT_ENTRIES 1000
     441             : 
     442             : #if defined(PLATFORM_LIKELY_MEMORY_CONSTRAINED)
     443             : // A 1ms sampling interval has been shown to be a large perf hit (10fps) on
     444             : // memory-constrained (low-end) platforms, and additionally to yield different
     445             : // results from the profiler. Where this is the important case, b2g, there are
     446             : // also many gecko processes which magnify these effects.
     447             : # define PROFILE_DEFAULT_INTERVAL 10
     448             : #else
     449             : #define PROFILE_DEFAULT_INTERVAL 1
     450             : #endif
     451             : 
     452             : #define PROFILE_DEFAULT_FEATURES NULL
     453             : #define PROFILE_DEFAULT_FEATURE_COUNT 0

     458             : public:

     460             :   // need to copy them then.

     549             : // Asynchronous Procedure Calls (APCs).

     551             : public:
     552             :   GeckoProfilerThreadWakeRAII()
     553             :     : mIssuedWake(profiler_thread_is_sleeping())
     554             :   {
